And we've been at a point where non fungible, tokens and JPEGs really have everybody's attention now. And although some people do see the space as a marketing opportunity and may use it to make a quick buck, I think most of us here today do see the real value behind NFTs and are looking to build a product or service with long term incentives around their communities. I'm sure most of us here have experienced what it's like to onboard into crypto, go through an on ramp, send the first on chain transaction, run out of gas, get a failed transaction, or even mint NFTs. And I think we can all agree that we can leverage all the open source tools and really all the amazing talent that's jumping into this space to continue to design the ideal user experiences for Web Three commerce. I think our goal here today is to hopefully nudge you a little bit into letting us join you along for that ride. So what we're building at Circle is a very simple solution for NFT platforms and applications to onboard users into crypto in a scalable fashion, and we'd love to talk to you about what that means. Exactly. So at its core, circles building Internet, native payments and treasury infrastructure, all based on USDC. We think that part of that long term value creation that we spoke about the first couple of slides comes with having a very seamless and trusted user experience, specifically around Payments, and more importantly, with users who are not necessarily crypto native into the applications that we're building. So throughout the next couple of slides, I'd love to just talk a little bit about USDC, about our APIs, and how our fiat infrastructure can help us seamlessly connect crypto with traditional finance. So let's start with USDC. 2021 was a great year for USDC. Together with everybody here, we've grown USDC supply about ten x, and 90% of that still lives on Ethereum. So looking forward to 2022, what that means is there's now much more liquidity, much more volume, and more blockchains to build interoperable commerce on Web three. For us, it's really about the USDC governance, its regulatory footing, and the trust from everybody here, the crypto community, the Ethereum community that's allowed developers and builders to design blockchain applications that leverage USDC payments with confidence. So let's dig into payments. We believe that crypto native goods do deserve crypto native payments. With Circle, you can send and receive blockchain payments across our supported blockchains with a super simple API integration. And something we're currently testing in beta is BTC and ETH payments as well, which we're super excited about. But as most of you know, onboarding net new users into crypto is not super easy, and it does involve going beyond the blockchain payments, which is why our payments infrastructure was designed to enable businesses and projects of all sizes to easily bridge in and out of crypto. So our APIs allow you to accept traditional payment methods, cards and ACH for your customers to buy digital goods in a method that they're still familiar with, maybe while they're still learning to use something like a MetaMask wallet. And just as importantly, we support programmatic Payouts in ACH and also wires back to creators, to developers and sellers that are already interacting with your platform so that you can reach more people in more countries. So the next question is, really, how does this all come together now that we're going beyond just sending and receiving payments? And we're thinking about designing a more robust same marketplace experience? With Circle, you can actually integrate both Payments and Payout functionality, the functionality that we just covered, really, with the ability to create user accounts and manage balances. So what this ultimately does is it essentially enables us to create scalable, a compliant marketplace solution that lets you focus on the design, on the creative aspects of your NFT, and on the minting and custody of your NFTs while you look at Cirque as the core financial architecture to your platform. So with one API integration, you can stand up user accounts, you can top them up with USDC from an external wallet, or you can top it up with fiat from card to ACH. And more importantly, you can design highly customizable funds flows the way that you see fit. So in the end, we provide you with all the tools that you need to position your product for growth across users, across blockchain ecosystems, with the blockchain partners and the blockchain that we support for USDC while still allowing you to stand up compliant digital marketplace with confidence. Great example of how we've been able to do so is with Dapper Labs, in which beyond the initial sale of a CryptoKitty or a TOPSHOT pack, buyers and sellers could connect up to this marketplace, and they're able to do peer to peer transactions. Or if they'd like to keep funds on the Dapper platform, they can. Or if they'd like to withdraw them on chain through an external USDC wallet, they can do so as well. So it's really, whether it's a blockchain based game managing, in game tokens or a sports NFT platform that's looking to enable trade within their community, circle really acts as the core financial layer of that digital marketplace. So with that, I'm going to pause there and I'm going to hand it over to Alison, who's really going to talk to us about what this looks like in practice and hopefully share some resources to inspire you and let us join you in that journey towards building Web three commerce. So over to you, Allison.

Compatible with Circle. The first is the Payments API, and that is kind of what it sounds like. It allows you to accept payments both fiat and crypto native payments from your end users. So in terms of the fiat side, we're talking mainly cards, ACH, Sepa, and Wires cards probably being the most popular among most users. And then on the crypto native side, that is going to be multi chain USDC again on eight of those blockchains that we support today, and then also Ether and BTUC payments coming soon.
